The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the K2 Pure Solutions ECU and Bleach Plant

The K2 Pure Solutions ECU and Bleach Plant is a salt to bleach plant intended to substantially reduce the number of chlorine railcars on the national railroad system.  K2 Pure Solutions is committed to being a responsible member of the Contra Costa County community and any other community in which it sets up future operations.  K2 Pure Solutions' motto, which appears on all company literature, is "Making Life Safer".  Corporate philosophy requires that facilities continuously identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of inherently safer technology and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in K2 Pure's EH&S Policy which reads:

"Protection of safety, health, environment and community is our overriding priority. All adverse incidents can and must be prevented."

 K2 Pure Solutions stresses safe and environmentally sound operations in employee training programs, and in written materials available at the Plant.  K2 Pure Solutions safety and environmental programs include monthly safety meeting of all employees and a joint worker/company Safety Committee.  There will be regularly scheduled internal safety and environmental audits conducted by K2 Pure Solutions personnel and periodic safety and environmental audits of the Plant conducted by independent, third party auditors.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Description of Stationary Source

The K2 Pure Solutions ECU and Bleach Plant is located at 950 Loveridge Road in Pittsburg California.  It is located entirely with the security fence line of The Dow Chemical Company.  The plant consists of two distinct manufacturing plants.

The first plant is for the production of electrochemical units (ECUs) for Dow.  An ECU is a measure of ch

loralkali production consisting of 1.1 ton of sodium hydroxide and 1.0 ton of chlorine.

The second plant is designed to produce bleach from ECUs produced by the ECU plant.

The bleach plant is capable of producing up to 304,000 gallons of 12.5% bleach solution per day.

Description of the Process

The K2 Pure Solutions ECU and Bleach Plant will contain the following chlorine systems:

-    Electrolyzers (3) producing a maximum of 300 tons / day of chlorine.

-    Chlorine Purification and Liquefaction Process where water is removed and chlorine gas is converted to chlorine liquid. This consists of two proof tanks each with 100 tons capacity at 2 psig.

-    High Grade Liquid Chlorine Storage which consists of two tanks each with 200 tons of capacity at 50 psig.

-    Low Grade Liquid Chlorine Storage which consists of two tanks each with 50 tons of capacity at 2 psig.

-    Chlorine Vaporization; Dow Chemical Chlorine Supply

-    Chlorine Vaporization; Bleach Production Unit

Chlorine is generated as a wet, hot, low pressure gas (4 PSIG & 190oF) by the electrolysis of brine at a maximum rate of 300 tons per day (100% basis). The gas exits the electrolyzers and is then cooled in two steps to remove most of the water. A portion of the cooled gas may be diverted to make sodium hypochlorite "bleach". The remainder enters a series of towers in which the rest of the water is removed by direct contact with sulfuric acid.

Once the water is removed, the gas is approximately 97% chlorine by volume with the other 3% being comprised of mostly oxygen, carbon dioxide and nitrogen. This dry gas is then cooled by contacting it with liquid chlorine in the Suction Chiller. A portion of the liquid feed is not vaporized and is removed from the bottom of the Suction Chiller to the Low Grade Chlorine Storage Tanks. Each of these storage tanks, which are maintained at 2 PSIG, has a maximum capacity of 50 tons of chlorine. One tank is operated normally empty and the other is maintained with some inventor

y (50 tons or less).

The cooled gas and the liquid that flashes in the Suction Chiller are then compressed to approximately 75 PSIG. A portion of the compressed gas (up to 100 tons/day) is diverted to make sodium hypochlorite "bleach" by direct contact with a solution of sodium hydroxide. All of the remaining compressed gas (up to 200 tons/day) is converted to liquid chlorine when the gas is cooled in two stages of refrigeration. The liquid chlorine from the liquefaction step is collected in the Chlorine Proof Tanks. Each of these storage tanks, which are maintained at 2 PSIG, has a maximum capacity of 100 tons of chlorine. These tanks are operated so that one is being filled while the other is being emptied.

Liquid chlorine collected in the Chlorine Proof Tanks is analyzed to verify that it meets the quality specification requirements, and is then transferred to the High Grade Chlorine Storage Tanks. Each of these storage tanks, which are maintained at 50 PSIG, has a maximum capacity of 200 tons of chlorine. During operations, one tank is normally empty and the other is maintained with some inventory (200 tons or less).

Liquid collected in the Low Grade Chlorine Storage Tanks is vaporized and used to supplement the chlorine flow to the sodium hypochlorite "bleach" plant. Liquid in the High Grade Chlorine Storage Tanks is vaporized and used to supply Dow with chlorine via pipeline. None of the chlorine is loaded into railcars, ton containers, or any other form of transport vessel.

In addition to various meteorological parameters that could lessen the off-site consequences, the facility has the following engineering controls in place to reduce the amount of a release that are not allowed to be considered when preparing the worst case release:

-    Area monitors to detect and alarm when chlorine is detected in the atmosphere.

-    Ability to transfer chlorine from a leaking tank to another tank via a pump and / or padding system.

-    Ability to vent and evacuate a tank

to a neutralization system.

-    Vacuum systems that enable operators to locate hoses at a leak point and suck leakages to a neutralization system.

-    Excess flow check valves located on all well lines in the tank (designed to shut off automatically if a major leak occurs in the piping).

-    Trained emergency response personnel equipped with sealing systems and Personal Protective Equipment to stop chlorine leaks.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Management System

The K2 Pure Solutions Pittsburg Plant operates under a formal management system based on CCPS Plant Guidelines for Technical Management of Chemical Process Safety to plan, organize, implement and control the risk management program elements.  This management system satisfies the requirements of Section 2735.6of the CalARP regulation and ensures that the risk management program elements are developed and continually improved.  All records associated with the prevention program elements will be retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation.  

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The prevention programs described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment.  Many of these prevention programs (e.g., PHAs, compliance audits, incident investigation) result in the development and implementation of additional safeguards (administrative and engineering controls).  Those recommendations that are planned for implementation at the K2 Pure Solutions Pittsburg Plant will be discussed in "Planned Changes to Improve Safety".  Those applicable safeguards that have already been implemented or that were part of the original design are described below.  These safeguards prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of regulated substances.  All covered processes have control systems designed to maintain operating parameters (t

emperature, pressures, flow, level) within allowable limits.  The covered processes are also equipped with alarms to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed the allowable limits, along with interlocks to prevent operation outside of allowable limits.  K2 Pure Solutions has developed procedures and conducts training of personnel to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding allowable limits (safety and operability) to ensure the correct response to the alarms.  The following chemical-specific safeguards also exist at the stationary source: 

-    The plant is equipped with 28 perimeter chlorine monitors placed in an array designed to detect any chlorine release at the detection limit of the monitors at the perimeter.

-    All vessels and piping in chlorine service were designed in accordance with Chlorine Institute design standards.

-    The Emergency Vent Scrubber is equipped with a chlorine monitor interlocked to shut the plant down in the event of a scrubber break through.    Prevent operation of the plant in the event of an Emergency Vent Scrubber Failure scrubber failure.

-    The Emergency Vent Scrubber is equipped with redundant draft fans equipped with auto start of the offline spare if the online fan fails.    

-    The Emergency Vent Scrubber is equipped with redundant caustic recirculation pumps equipped with auto start of the offline spare if the online pump fails

-    The chlorine compressor is equipped with numerous temperature interlocks to initiate shutdown if parameters are exceeded.

-    The chlorine compressor is equipped with numerous vibration interlocks to initiate shutdown if parameters are exceeded\

-    The rectifiers are interlocked to trip if the EVS experiences high ORP.

-    The rectifiers are interlocked to trip if the EVS experiences low recirculation tank level.

-    The rectifiers are interlocked to trip if the EVS experiences low caustic recirculation flow.     Prevent operation of the plant in the event of an Emergency Vent Scrubber Failure

scrubber failure.    

-    The rectifiers are interlocked to trip if the EVS experiences high caustic recirculation temperature.    

 

Prevention Program Elements

The K2 Pure Solutions Pittsburg Plant maintains Pittsburg Safety Standards for each of the following elements to align with EPA RMP, CalARP, CalOSHA PSM, and OSHA PSM regulations. These elements include:

Process Safety Information

All employees of the Pittsburg Plant shall have available to them written process safety information that will enable them to identify and understand the hazards posed by every process within the plant.

Process Hazard Analysis

New facilities and/or processes and significant process changes to existing facilities in the K2 Pure Solutions Pittsburg Plant shall be subject to a hazard review prior to start-up.

Operating Procedures

Operating procedures must be current and technically accurate. All written operating procedures must be understandable by even the most inexperienced employee, and therefore must be written with that thought in mind.  Written operating procedures will be used for initial employee training as well as required refresher training for experienced employees.

Training

All employees involved in operating, maintaining and supervising a process facility will be trained in an overview of the process and receive task or position-specific training to provide the necessary skills and knowledge to safely and competently perform their job functions.

Mechanical Integrity

A well-established mechanical integrity program ensures that equipment critical to process safety is fabricated to meet process specifications, installed correctly, and maintained in a safe operating condition. It also allows maintenance employees to preemptively identify and correct equipment deficiencies to avoid associated incidents and down time. The K2 Pure Solutions ECU and Bleach Plant has therefore developed a mechanical integrity program which is comprised of the programs and procedures show

n below. The mechanical integrity program applies to pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps and additional equipment deemed by operating and maintenance personnel to be important to safety (e.g., heat exchangers, rotating equipment, electrical equipment, and fire protection equipment)

Management of Change

It is K2 Pure's philosophy to pursue continuous improvement in all aspects of plant operation. The purpose of this standard is to define the procedure and authority levels for making plant changes in the implementation of continuous improvement in a manner that allows for team input. This will assure plant safety, environmental responsibility, product quality, and efficient plant operation.

Pre-Start-Up Safety Review

To assure all major safety aspects of new projects are adequately reviewed by necessary personnel and to minimize the risk of personal injury or loss of equipment a project safety review will be conducted for all projects or process changes that are:

-    New to the Pittsburg plant.

-    Being scaled up or scaled down in .

-    Being modified to an extent that, in the judgment of the project manager, department managers, or plant manager, warrants a review for new hazards.

-    When the project is significant enough to require a change to the Process Safety Information.

Compliance Audits

In the interest of continued safe operation of the Pittsburg Plant, as well as compliance with the law, K2 Pure Solutions believes that a frequent and robust compliance audit process is mandatory.  K2 Pure will work in cooperation with the Dow Chemical Company, third party consulting auditors and CCCHSD , in addition to conducting internal audits, to ensure the Accidental Release Prevention processes at the plant are always maintained in robust condition.

Incident Investigation

All incidents, no matter how minor, whether personal injury or chemical release, shall be reported immediatel

y to the immediate supervisor for investigation and evaluation. Since every accident includes a sequence of contributing causes, it may be possible to avoid a repeat performance of the first event by recognizing and eliminating these causes. The removal of a single cause may prevent a recurrence.

Employee Participation

The policy of K2 Pure Solutions Pittsburg plant is to actively encourage employee participation in all aspects of process safety management.

Hot Work Permit

Establishing minimum standards for the performance of safe welding, cutting, brazing, grinding, or wherever the use of open flames or other spark producing equipment is used is vital to reduce the possibility of injuries to personnel and/or damages to plant facilities that could result from welding, cutting, brazing, grinding, use of open flames and electrical tools.  A Hot Work or Fire Permit Form shall be used in all situations where hot work is performed.

Contractors

K2 Pure Solutions recognizes that the use of contractors is vital to the safe operation of the Pittsburg Plant.  However, since they are not routine workers in our plant, they have a limited understanding of our processes and may have different approaches doing work.  It is important that K2 Pure Solutions bring in only qualified contractors and ensure that they perform to the highest standards of safety.  This is accomplished through pre-qualification, education, and field auditing of contractors selected to perform work at K2 chemical process and storage areas.

The Five-Year Accident History

K2 Pure Pittsburg has had one accidental release of chlorine in the history of the plant. This release involved the removal of a slip blind at three manual valves. A small release occurred which exposed a maintenance worker resulting in one day away from work.

The Emergency Response Program

The K2 Pure Solutions Emergency Response Plan has been developed to prepare our employees to respond in the event of a chemical release, fire of

medical emergency in way that protects life, property and the community while protecting our employees from unnecessary risk.  The Plan consists of 11 elements:

-    General Section 

-    Emergency Coordination and Communications

-    Facility Plot Plan and Hazardous Wastes, Chemical Storage Areas

-    Accountability, Assembly, and Evacuation 

-    Reporting

-    Calculations and Reportable Quantities

-    Rescue and Medical

-    Emergency Procedures

-    Decontamination

-    Emergency Equipment

-    Hazard Communication

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Since the K2 Pure Solutions ECU and Bleach Plant is a new facility, every effort has been made to bring the plant on-line in the safest configuration possible.  Of course, potential improvements will be identified as we execute our PSM processes (PHA, Audit, Pre-Startup Safety Review, etc) and we will capture and prioritize them through our Corrective Action Review process.
